item.title: Jerusalem Journal: A House-by-House Struggle for Control of a Jerusalem Neighborhood
item.description: In East Jerusalem, late-night move-ins by Jewish settlers are raising tensions and questions about ownership of the properties.
item.dc:creator: By ISABEL KERSHNER
item.media:description: Mahmoud Karain, right, argued with a police officer after Jewish settlers moved into a home that he said was owned by a relative.

item.title: U.S. Steps Up Strikes on Embattled Syrian Town, Aided by Data From Kurds
item.description: Kurdish officials said the intensified attacks in Kobani had allowed them to regain territory and push the militants back on several fronts.
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.dc:creator: By ERIC SCHMITT and KAREEM FAHIM
item.media:description: Kurdish fighters taking up positions, in Kobani, Syria, on Wednesday. The town has been under siege by the Islamic State.

item.title: General Escalates Libya Attack
item.description: The general, Khalifa Hifter, has led a six-month campaign to rid the violence-torn country of Islamists.
item.dc:creator: By SULIMAN ALI ZWAY and DAVID D. KIRKPATRICK

item.title: ‘Substantial Work’ Said to Remain in Iran Nuclear Talks
item.description: Negotiators face a Nov. 24 deadline for an accord to trade significant constraints on Iran’s nuclear activities in return for a lifting of onerous economic sanctions.
item.dc:creator: By MICHAEL R. GORDON
item.media:description: Secretary of State John Kerry met on Wednesday in Vienna with Catherine Ashton, the foreign policy chief for the European Union, and Mohammad Javad Zarif, the Iranian foreign minister.

item.title: Blast in Somali Capital Kills at Least 5
item.description: The attack, the second of its kind in two days in Mogadishu, took place at outside a cafe where students frequently gather.
item.dc:creator: By MOHAMMED IBRAHIM

item.title: Open Source: Activist on Trial for Tearing Photo of Bahrain’s King Repeats Act in Court
item.description: Bahrain once again jailed Zainab al-Khawaja, a prominent opposition activist, for tearing up a photograph King Hamad bin Isa al-Khalifa.
item.category: Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )
Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.dc:creator: By ROBERT MACKEY

item.title: As Oil Prices Plummet, Saudi Arabia Faces a Test of Strategy
item.description: Saudi officials have signaled that they are prepared to endure reduced profits rather than cut production in an effort to prop up prices, as they did to their later regret in the early 1980s.
item.category: Organization of the Petroleum Exporting Countries
item.dc:creator: By BEN HUBBARD and CLIFFORD KRAUSS
item.media:description: Ali al-Naimi, the Saudi oil minister, in June. He has said that lower prices are no cause for alarm.

item.title: Finally, a Name for ISIS Strikes: Operation Inherent Resolve
item.description: The United States Central Command said the name was meant to reflect “the unwavering resolve” of the nation and its partners to eliminate the militant group.
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.dc:creator: By THE NEW YORK TIMES

item.title: At War Against ISIS, Iraqi Premier Is Facing Battles Closer to Home
item.description: As Iraq fights the Islamic State, Prime Minister Haider al-Abadi is also battling critics in his own party and the Shiite bloc it leads.
item.dc:creator: By KIRK SEMPLE

item.title: Suspected Qaeda Operative Tries to Quash Rights Waiver
item.description: Nazih Abdul-Hamed al-Ruqai testified in Manhattan courtroom that he felt he had “no choice” but to sign away his rights after being seized in Libya last year by United States commandos.
item.dc:creator: By BENJAMIN WEISER

item.title: In Britain, ‘Stupidity’ Defense Has a Drawback
item.description: After his acquittal from the phone hacking scandal, Charles Brooks sought to be reimbursed by the government for the legal costs of his defense.
item.category: Wiretapping and Other Eavesdropping Devices and Methods
item.dc:creator: By KATRIN BENNHOLD

item.title: Fall in Oil Prices Poses a Problem for Russia, Iraq and Others
item.description: From Moscow to Caracas, Riyadh to Baghdad, in Tehran, Algiers, Kuwait City and Lagos, officials are confronting the plunge in prices — roughly 25 percent since a peak in June.
item.category: Organization of the Petroleum Exporting Countries
item.dc:creator: By DAVID M. HERSZENHORN

item.title: 10 Injured as Migrants Storm Spanish Border Fence
item.description: The Spanish government says some 300 African migrants scaled fences six meters high to try to enter Spain’s northwest African enclave city of Melilla.
item.dc:creator: By THE ASSOCIATED PRESS
item.media:description: Spanish police officers on Wednesday stopped one of the almost 300 people who tried to cross from Morocco to Melilla, a Spanish territory in North Africa.

item.title: World Briefing: Saudi Arabia: Cleric Sentenced to Death
item.description: A widely revered Shiite Muslim cleric was convicted Wednesday of sedition and other charges and sentenced to death.
item.dc:creator: By THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: World Briefing: Philippines: American Marine Accused of Murdering a Transgender Filipino
item.description: The police filed a murder complaint against an American Marine on Wednesday, accusing him of killing a transgender Filipino whom he met at a bar.
item.dc:creator: By THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: World Briefing: Algeria: Police Officers Stage Protest
item.description: Algerian police officers tried to push their way into President Abdelaziz Bouteflika’s headquarters in a protest prompted by violence against security forces in the south.
item.dc:creator: By THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: World Briefing: Mexico: Camel Attack Kills American
item.description: A Chicago man who owned a wildlife park in the resort of Tulum has died after being kicked, bitten and sat on by a camel.
item.dc:creator: By THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: Op-Ed Contributor: Resurrecting Smallpox? Easier Than You Think
item.description: The virus’s genome is already online. You just need the right lab.
item.dc:creator: By LEONARD ADLEMAN

item.title: Competition Is Tough for Most Coveted Seat at the United Nations
item.description: Nations throw parties, give gifts and make deals years in advance to try to get other nations to vote their envoys to seats on the United Nations Security Council.
item.dc:creator: By SOMINI SENGUPTA
item.media:description: The Turkish foreign minister, Mevlut Cavusoglu, center, and his Spanish counterpart, José Manuel García-Margallo, left.

item.title: Car Bomb Kills 8 Afghans From Unit Linked to C.I.A.
item.description: It was the latest of several clashes to take a heavy toll on the security forces as American combat forces leave the country.
item.dc:creator: By DECLAN WALSH

item.title: Blizzard and Avalanche Kill at Least 20 Trekkers in Himalayas
item.description: The victims included at least nine foreigners, and heavy snow forced the suspension of rescue operations until Thursday.
item.dc:creator: By BHADRA SHARMA and NIDA NAJAR
item.media:description: In a photo released by the Nepalese Army, emergency responders carried a victim of the avalanche away from the site.

item.title: Beating of Democracy Advocate in Hong Kong Fuels Public Outcry
item.description: A video showing an attack on a Hong Kong democracy advocate, apparently by the police, added to tensions between the protesters and the beleaguered government.
item.dc:creator: By KEITH BRADSHER and MICHAEL FORSYTHE

item.title: Open Source: Soccer Match in Serbia Erupts in Riot Set Off by Drone
item.description: A match between the national teams of Serbia and Albania collapsed in chaos caused by a drone carrying a political message.
item.dc:creator: By ROBERT MACKEY

item.title: Misstated Excerpt of Times Article Offers Fresh Take on President Sisi of Egypt
item.description: After the article appeared in The Times, the flagship state newspaper, Al Ahram, misstated parts of it in an apparent effort to burnish the Egyptian president’s image.
item.dc:creator: By THE NEW YORK TIMES
item.media:description: President Abdel Fattah el-Sisi of Egypt preparing to deliver a speech to the United Nations General Assembly last month.

item.title: Siege Possible as ISIS Nears Strategic Town in Iraq
item.description: Conquering the town in the embattled province of Anbar would connect two jihadist strongholds.
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.dc:creator: By KIRK SEMPLE and ALI HAMZA
